item.title: The Roots of Britain’s Economic Malaise
item.description: There are five issues that any UK government must address in order to bring about a robust economic recovery, beginning with launching a process to rejoin the European single market or customs union. But rationalizing spending on the National Health Service, pensions, and welfare benefits will require considerably more courage.

item.title: Europe’s Electric Straitjacket
item.description: Reaching climate neutrality by 2050 is non-negotiable, but it is impossible to know in 2025 the best way to get there. Rather than attempt to dictate the pathway now, EU policymakers must design a strategy that leaves space for unexpected innovations and adequately accounts for geopolitical risk.

item.title: Trump’s Pardon Racket
item.description: The pardon power is the only authority the US Constitution places entirely in the president’s hands, immune from legislative override or judicial review. For Alexander Hamilton, who assumed that shame would restrain abuse, Donald Trump is the nightmare scenario.

item.title: America Will Pay for Pushing India Away
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin’s visit to New Delhi should be a wake-up call for the United States: attempting to coerce India into actions that compromise its national interest is a recipe for estrangement. Given that India remains crucial to balance China’s aggressive rise, such an outcome would carry high costs for the US.

item.title: Trump Wants to Make Europe White Again
item.description: The new US National Security Strategy represents a decisive departure from the universalist values that have guided US foreign policy since 1945. Its nativist, anti-liberal stance should dispel any remaining European illusions about the current state of the transatlantic alliance.

item.title: European Tech Sovereignty Requires Digital Leverage, Not Self-Sufficiency
item.description: The European Union cannot reduce its digital dependence by investing in infrastructure that leaves underlying power relationships intact. Real power comes from controlling the parts of the value chain that shape decision-making, govern data flows, and set the standards that structure digital markets.

item.title: Trump’s United States of the Americas
item.description: The Trump administration’s new National Security Strategy envisions a world in which the United States no longer anchors alliances and international institutions, stands up for democracy and human rights, or seeks to uphold the global balance of power. Russia and China will find much opportunity in this new world.

item.title: María Corina Machado’s Catholic Revolution
item.description: Across the US political spectrum, there is little understanding of how important Catholic politics have been in shaping the Latin American right. But to understand the situation in Venezuela requires recognizing the fundamental role of the tradition of Christian Democracy.

item.title: Britain’s Fiscal Watchdog Doesn't See What Matters
item.description: By ignoring the long-run effects of both government-funded and privately funded innovation, Britain's official budget scorer has been systematically underestimating the economy's potential output and the government's future fiscal headroom. The result is not fiscal discipline, but a costly illusion.

item.title: The Critical-Minerals Race Is Putting the Planet at Risk
item.description: As governments weaken environmental protections to promote new mining projects, the global scramble for critical minerals is deepening social divides and harming vital ecosystems. Only reduced consumption and robust, enforceable rules can prevent long-term harm and protect basic human rights.

item.title: The Transformative Power of Early Childhood Education
item.description: In a world marked by volatility, no investment yields greater economic returns than supporting children in their first five or six years of life. Yet pre-primary education remains chronically underfunded, blocking the surest route to a more prosperous, peaceful, and stable world.

item.title: India and the Gulf States Could Reshape Global Trade
item.description: In an increasingly multipolar world, India and the Gulf states are no longer merely trading partners but strategic actors in their own right. Together, they are advancing a model of cooperation that values autonomy, transparency, and mutual gain over coercion and dependence on great powers.

item.title: Europe’s Tech Firms Need Regulation to Grow
item.description: The European Commission's rushed plan to water down landmark dig’ital legislation reflects the view that excessive regulation is to blame for the lack of European firms capable of competing with the US tech giants. This logic is fundamentally flawed, and deregulation is destined to backfire.

item.title: Trump’s Authoritarian Innovations
item.description: During his second presidency, Donald Trump has joined a long line of autocrats who come to power through elections only to erode democracy, with the ultimate goal of installing an authoritarian regime. But much about his first year back in office more closely resembles the aftermath of coups.

item.title: Why Peace in Ukraine Remains a Distant Prospect
item.description: When two warring parties’ core objectives are fundamentally incompatible, no amount of external pressure or diplomacy can bridge the gap between them. Peace in Ukraine will come eventually, but it almost certainly will not come from US President Donald Trump's current diplomatic push, no matter how many deadlines he sets.

item.title: Eurasia’s Great Water Gamble
item.description: Climate change is rapidly melting the glaciers that feed Central Asia’s rivers, pushing the region toward an ecological tipping point. Against this backdrop, a new initiative aims to revive a long-abandoned plan to redirect part of Siberia’s freshwater to its southern neighbors.

item.title: Japan Talks Tough
item.description: Japan’s new prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, was not wrong when she recently said that the country must be prepared to defend itself even beyond its borders. But she would be in a stronger position to strengthen Japan’s military muscle if she were willing to reckon with her political forebears’ war crimes.

item.title: Trump’s Ukraine Peace Plan Means More War
item.description: After attempting to impose draconian peace terms on Ukraine, the US delegation responsible for negotiating with Russian President Vladimir Putin, who all but dictated those terms, has once again failed to achieve a breakthrough. Even if the Trump administration does manage to get a peace agreement signed, what it contains – and what it omits – is likely to be a formula for renewed conflict.

item.title: The Big Picture
Ecuador’s Warning to Trump
item.description: By rejecting all four ballot measures in a recent referendum, Ecuadorian voters demonstrated an understanding that neither their right-wing president, Daniel Noboa, nor Donald Trump seems to share. Militarizing poor neighborhoods and inviting US troops is no way to resolve a security crisis.
